objectives: Identify key pronunciation differences from English
Recognize accent marks and their function

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Maestra
dialogue_blocks.translation: How do you spell your name?
dialogue_blocks.context: Asking someone to spell their name

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Alumno
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [mi ˈnombɾe es ˈektoɾ ‖ atʃe aˈke θe te o ˈeɾe]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Maestra
dialogue_blocks.translation: Good. And how is the 'ñ' pronounced?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ˈβjen ‖ i ˈkomo se pɾonˈunθja la ˈeɲe]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Alumno
dialogue_blocks.text: La 'ñ' suena como 'ny' en inglés, como en 'canyon'.
dialogue_blocks.translation: The 'ñ' sounds like 'ny' in English, like in 'canyon'.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [la ˈeɲe ˈswena ˈkomo ˈni en inˈɡles ‖ ˈkomo en ˈkaɲon]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Maestra
dialogue_blocks.text: Correcto. ¿Y las vocales? ¿Cómo son en español?
dialogue_blocks.translation: Correct. And the vowels? What are they like in Spanish?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [koˈrekto ‖ i las βoˈkales ‖ ˈkomo son en espaˈɲol]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Alumno
dialogue_blocks.text: Las vocales siempre suenan igual: a, e, i, o, u.
dialogue_blocks.translation: Vowels always sound the same: a, e, i, o, u.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [las βoˈkales ˈsjempɾe ˈswenan iˈɡwal ‖ a e i o u]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Maestra
dialogue_blocks.text: ¿Qué significa el acento escrito, como en 'café'?
dialogue_blocks.translation: What does the written accent mean, as in 'café'?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ke siɡˈnifika el aˈθento esˈkɾito ‖ ˈkomo en kaˈfe]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Alumno
dialogue_blocks.text: El acento indica cuál sílaba se pronuncia más fuerte.
dialogue_blocks.translation: The accent shows which syllable is stressed most strongly.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [el aˈθento inˈðika ˈkwal ˈsilaβa se pɾonˈunθja mas ˈfweɾte]

srs_flashcards.back: Spanish vowels — always short and pure (never diphthongs)
[ɲ] — like 'ny' in canyon: mañana, español, niño
Both pronounced [ʝ] in Mexico — like English 'y'
[x] — strong guttural h sound: jota, gente, gitano
Always silent in Spanish: hola [ˈola], hotel [oˈtel]
written accent — marks stressed syllable or distinguishes meaning

exercises.question: The letter 'h' in Spanish is always:

options.text: Pronounced differently depending on the word

feedback.correct: ¡Correcto! 'H' is always silent in Spanish: hola, hotel, hablar.
feedback.incorrect: Unlike English, Spanish 'h' is completely silent in all words.

exercises.instruction: Une la letra con su sonido en español

speaking_rubric.title: Deletrea tu nombre (Spell your name)
speaking_rubric.scenario: Give your full name and spell it out letter by letter in Spanish.
speaking_rubric.prompt: Di tu nombre completo y deletréalo en español.

sample_response.text: Me llamo Ana García. A-N-A, G-A-R-C-Í-A.
sample_response.ipa: [me ˈʝamo ˈana ɡaɾˈθia ‖ a ˈene ˈa ‖ ˈxe ˈa ˈeɾe θe ˈi ˈa]

cultural_notes.formality: In Mexico, the alphabet is taught with these letter names: a, be, ce, de, e, efe, ge, hache, i, jota, ka, ele, eme, ene, eñe, o, pe, cu, erre, ese, te, u, uve, doble uve, equis, ye, zeta. Learning these is essential for spelling out names and words.
cultural_notes.gestures: When spelling, Mexicans often count letters on their fingers or write in the air to help the listener follow.
cultural_notes.regional_variations: In Mexico, 'll' and 'y' are both pronounced [ʝ] (yeísmo). The letters 'b' and 'v' are identical in pronunciation [β/b] — this causes many spelling errors even for native speakers.
